div1.p: Truby provides Tate with information about Captain Alexander N. Stark.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Paul L. Tate, January 15, 1950
div1.opener:
Stick [with] p(18)
question 82 +
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO 18, CALIFORNIA
Jan. 15/50
Dear Tate,
div1.p:
I appreciated your letter of
Nov. 29 very much and regret that the holiday
season and other things caused me
to put off letter writing to a great
extent.

I enjoyed your reminiscing about
the “Cuban atmosphere” we found these 50
years ago. You may be sure it stands
out most clearly and pleasantly in my
memory as it does in yours.

You asked about Capt. Stark. He become
one of the best friends I have ever had. When
he left Cuba he went to West Point for duty.
There he did all of the surgery and was
soon worked to death. Then he ask the
S.G. to send me there as his asst. We
made a good team, I think, & got away with
a big job in excellent shape. I was with
him until I became a Capt. and then
the S.G. sent me to a station of my own
on the Pacific Coast. After that Stark & I did
not serve together. He was the Chief Surgeon
of the 1st Army in France during World War I
and did wonderful work. sheHe should have
been made a General Officer, but some one
who was not friendly to Stark, blocked it.
C2
B7
After that he was sent to Texas for
duty and was heartbroken and soon
was retired for phisical disability heart I think.
while I was in Command of the Letterman
Hospital in San Francisco in 1922 or '23 he
sent me a telegram asking if we had
a room for him in the hospital as
he was sick. I answered at once, and
urged him to come as we had a fine
heart specialist. A day or so later I
received word that he died soon after
my telegram came. He was a grand person
and a most efficient Medical Officer. He
did more for me in many ways than
anyone else I have ever served with.
I recommended that he be one of the
persons in the Wyeth painting, but the
people who decided the matter chose me
instead as Stark had left Cuba before
Lazear's work with mosquitoes brought results.
I was there at that time and during the
establishment of Camp Lazear. As C.O. I was
included among the others who were selected.
I am glad that Wyeth. Inc sent you
a large copy. I was also given a copy
marked No. 5

I hope you will find a copy of my
book. I think you will and then you
can review what I said about Dr. Ames, Lambert,
Mrs Warner and others who did great work, but
could not be included on the Roll of Honor.
When you write again tell me what
you are doing in Berkely and how things are
going with you.
